questions.question: Question 2: What is the most common hematologic manifestation seen in patients with HIV infection?
questions.explanation:
Anaemia is the most common hematologic abnormality associated with HIV infection. It affects 60–
80% of patients during the late stage. In most cases, the cause of anaemia in HIV-infected patients is multifactorial. It is often 
associated with infection, inflammation, malignancy, malnutrition, and polypharmacy. 332 
Sold by @itachibot Note: Prior to the use of potent antiretroviral therapy (ART), thrombocytopenia was a common 
finding in individuals infected with HIV. With use of potent ART, the incidence of 
thrombocytopenia is far lower.

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following anemia is not due to diminished erythropoiesis?
questions.explanation: Hereditary spherocytosis is not due to diminished erythropoiesis. It is a type of hemolytic anemia. Classification of anemia according to underlying mechanism: • Anemias of diminished erythropoiesis - decreased red cell production • Hemolytic anemias - increased red cell destruction • Anemia due to blood loss Anemias due to diminished erythropoiesis: • Iron deficiency anemia • Megaloblastic anemia • Anemia of chronic diseases • Aplastic anemia • Myelophthisic anemia • Fanconi's anemia

questions.question: Question 4: In a patient with MCV of 109 fl, which of the following is least likely?
questions.explanation:
MCV >100 fl indicates macrocytic anaemia which is not seen in anaemia of chronic disease. 
RBCs in anemia of chronic disease are initially normocytic and normochromic, becoming 
microcytic and hypochromic over time. Vitamin B12 deficiency, thiamine deficiency, and orotic aciduria cause macrocytic anaemia.

questions.question:
Question 5: A 30-year-old woman with iron deficiency anaemia is prescribed oral iron supplements. 
Foods containing which of the following can she take to increase its absorption?
questions.explanation:
Absorption of iron is increased by ascorbic acid. It is decreased by phosphates, oxalates, and 
carbonates.

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following contains most of the functional iron in the body?
questions.explanation:
Most of the functional iron (80%) in the body is found in hemoglobin. 333 
Sold by @itachibot The storage pool represented by hemosiderin, and ferritin contains about 15% to 20% of total 
body iron. Myoglobin and iron-containing enzymes such as catalase and the cytochromes contain 
the rest.

questions.question: Question 7: Which transporter is required for the transport of iron into the enterocyte?
questions.explanation:
DMT1 (divalent metal transporter 1) is required for the transport of iron into the enterocyte. Dietary iron is mostly in Fe3+ (ferric state) and must be reduced to Fe2+ (ferrous state) by 
ferrireductases. Fe2+ iron destined for circulation is transported from the cytoplasm across the 
basolateral enterocyte membrane by ferroportin 1. Hephaestin is an iron oxidase that converts Fe2+ to Fe3+

questions.question: Question 8: Which of the following is involved in iron metabolism?
questions.explanation:
Ceruloplasmin is involved in iron metabolism. Ferritin is the storage form of iron in the body. Ceruloplasmin and hephaestin help in oxidation of 
Fe2+ to Fe3+ at the basolateral border of enterocytes. This is coupled with transport through 
ferroportin. In plasma, iron is transported by transferrin. Haptocorrin and cubulin are involved in vitamin B12 absorption. Selenoprotein is involved in 
selenium metabolism. 334 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 9: Hepcidin inhibits iron transfer from the enterocyte to the plasma by binding to
questions.explanation:
Hepcidin inhibits iron transfer from the enterocytes into the plasma by binding to ferroportin, 
which is an iron efflux channel in the enterocyte. Iron metabolism is regulated by hepcidin, a protein and acute phase reactant produced by the 
liver. It binds to ferroportin and degrades it. This inhibits the transfer of iron from the enterocyte 
to the plasma via ferroportin. As a result, iron becomes trapped within the duodenal cells 
(enterocytes) in the form of mucosal ferritin and is lost in feces when these cells are shed off. Transcription of hepcidin is increased by the following factors: • Increased levels of iron • Inflammatory cytokines Transcription of hepcidin is decreased by the following factors: • Iron deficiency • Hypoxia • Ineffective erythropoiesis Hepcidin is encoded by the HAMP gene and its mutations are associated with hereditary 
hemochromatosis. 335 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 10: What is the main site of iron absorption?
questions.explanation: Absorption of iron mainly occurs in the proximal duodenum.

questions.question:
Question 11: Which of the following is true regarding the internal iron homeostasis in iron-deficiency 
anaemia?

options.a: Ferritin mRNA concentration iron-responsive element increases and ferritin synthesis
options.b: Transferrin receptor 1 iron-responsive elements increases transferrin receptor mRNA
options.c: Transferrin receptor 1 iron responsive elements decreases transferrin receptor mRNA
options.d: Ferritin mRNA concentration iron responsive element decreases and ferritin synthesis

questions.explanation:
In iron deficiency anaemia, there is an increase in transferrin receptor mRNA concentration and 
synthesis. Iron absorbed through diet or which is released from circulation is bound to transferrin (iron 
transfer protein). When erythropoiesis is stimulated, iron-transferrin complexes act as transferrin 
receptors on the surface of bone marrow erythroid cells. Through receptor-mediated endocytosis, 
this complex is internalised. This iron is then made available for heme synthesis while the transferrin-receptor complex is 
recycled to the surface of the cell, from where the transferrin is released back into circulation and 
the transferrin receptor re-anchors into the cell membrane. The excess iron after hemoglobin 
synthesis binds to apoferritin (storage protein), forming ferritin. Senescent RBCs undergo phagocytosis in the cells of the reticuloendothelial system. The 
hemoglobin is broken down, the globin and other proteins are returned to the amino acid pool, 
and the iron is shuttled back to the surface of the reticuloendothelial cell, where it is taken up by 
transferrin via ferroportin (iron export channel). There is no regulated excretory pathway for iron, and the only mechanisms by which iron is lost 
are blood loss (via gastrointestinal bleeding, menstruation, or other forms of bleeding) and the 
loss of epithelial cells from the skin, gut, and genitourinary tract. The normal daily iron loss from 
the body is 1-2 mg. 336

questions.question:
Question 12: Peripheral smear of a patient with koilonychia is given below. Which of the following lab 
findings is consistent with her likely diagnosis? 329 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given peripheral smear showing microcytic and hypochromic picture with pencil cells is 
suggestive of iron-deficiency anaemia. In this condition, TIBC is increased, transferrin saturation 
is decreased, and ferritin is decreased.

questions.question: Question 13: You would expect iron-deficiency anaemia in all of the following patients except:

options.c: A 54-year-old woman after Billroth II operation

questions.explanation:
Maize rich diet is not one of the causes of iron deficiency anaemia. It can cause pellagra. Iron deficiency anaemia can be caused by hookworm infestation, carcinoma of the cecum and in 
Billroth II operation.

questions.question: Question 14: Which of the following laboratory findings is seen in a patient with sideroblastic anaemia?
questions.explanation: In sideroblastic anemia, the transferrin saturation is increased. Serum iron and serum ferritin are also elevated.

questions.question: Question 15: Which of the following is not included in the triad of the Plummer-Vinson syndrome?
questions.explanation:
The triad of the Plummer-Vinson syndrome does not include koilonychia (marked as 2). Triad of Plummer–Vinson syndrome: • Esophageal webs • Microcytic hypochromic anaemia • Atrophic glossitis 337 
Sold by @itachibot Koilonychia is a symptom of iron deficiency anaemia. It may or may not be present in Plummer 
Vinson syndrome. Hence, it is not a part of the triad.

questions.question:
Question 16: A 34-year-old woman with severe anaemia was started on parenteral iron. Which of the 
following would occur first in this patient as a response to therapy?
questions.explanation:
One of the earliest responses to the correction of iron deficiency anaemia is increase in serum 
iron. Responses after initiation of treatment: • 12 to 24 hours - Replenishment of intracellular iron enzymes; decreased irritability; increased 
appetite; increase in serum iron. • 36 to 48 hours - Erythroid hyperplasia in bone marrow • 48 to 72 hours - Reticulocytosis, peaking at 5-7 days 338 
Sold by @itachibot • 4 to 30 days - Increase in hemoglobin level, increase in ferritin, increase in MCV • 1 to 3 months - Repletion of stores 339 
Sold by @itachibot Normocytic And Macrocytic Anemia
